title: 110_hr392
content: The Act is titled the "District of Columbia and United States Territories Circulating Quarter Dollar Program Act" and involves the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and each of the territories. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a new subsection for the redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars honoring the District of Columbia and the territories in 2009. The designs on the reverse side of the coins will be emblematic of the District of Columbia and the territories, with flexibility in the placement of inscriptions. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and territories. The inscriptions will be placed on the reverse side of the coins, with the value designation on the obverse side. Designs will be selected by the Secretary after consultation. The redesign and issuance of circulating quarter dollars in 2009 will feature designs emblematic of the District of Columbia and territories. Designs for quarter dollars shall be selected by the Secretary after consultation with the chief executive of the District of Columbia or the territory being honored, the Commission of Fine Arts, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Secretary has the sole discretion to approve designs for quarter dollars, with participation from various officials, artists, engravers, and the public. Designs must be dignified, and certain representations like head and shoulders portraits are prohibited. The Secretary has the authority to approve quarter dollar designs, with input from officials, artists, and the public. Designs must be dignified, and certain representations like head and shoulders portraits are prohibited. All coins minted under this subsection are considered numismatic items and can be issued in uncirculated, proof, or silver qualities. The Secretary has the authority to mint quarter dollars with 90 percent silver and 10 percent copper, honoring the District of Columbia and territories in sequential order during 2009. If the District of Columbia or any territory becomes a state before the 10-year period ends, different provisions will apply. If a territory becomes a state before the 10-year period ends, different provisions will apply. This subsection does not apply if a territory becomes independent or ceases to be a territory or possession of the United States before quarter dollars are minted with designs emblematic of that territory. The term 'territory' includes Puerto Rico, Guam, American Samoa, the US Virgin Islands, and the Northern Mariana Islands. The House of Representatives passed the bill on January 23, 2007. Karen L. Haas attested to it as the Clerk.
